During the 1919–20 English football season, Gillingham F.C. played in the Southern League Division One. It was the 22nd season in which the club competed in the Southern League, and the 21st in Division One; prior to the season, the club had been inactive for over four years due to the First World War. George Collins was appointed as the club's new manager, and most of the players were new; the club struggled to find a settled team during the season, fielding nearly 40 players, including six goalkeepers. The team's results included a run of 14 league games, from October to February, without a win. Gillingham finished bottom of the league table but nonetheless gained entry to the national Football League when it absorbed the entirety of the Southern League Division One.

Gillingham also competed in the FA Cup, requiring three replays to progress from the sixth qualifying round before losing in the first round proper. The team played 47 competitive matches, winning 11, drawing 10, and losing 26. Arthur Wood was the team's top goalscorer, with 12 goals in the league and 14 in total. Tom Leslie made the most appearances, playing 40 times. The highest attendance recorded at the club's home ground, Priestfield Road, was approximately 10,000 for league games against Swindon Town and Brighton & Hove Albion and an FA Cup match against Swansea Town.

Background and pre-season

Gillingham, founded in 1893 and known as New Brompton until 1912,[2] had played in the Southern League since the competition's formation in 1894. The team had been promoted from Division Two in 1895 and remained in Division One ever since but with minimal success, rarely finishing in the top half of the league table.[3] The 1919–20 season was the first time the Southern League operated after the First World War; Gillingham had not played a competitive match since the 1914–15 season, when they had finished bottom of the table.[3][4] Earlier in the year, the Southern League had proposed an amalgamation with the national Football League, but it was rejected.[5]

In July, George Collins was appointed as Gillingham's new manager in place of Sam Gilligan, who did not return to the club after the war. As was the norm at the time, Collins had responsibility for team tactics and training, but other tasks associated with a modern manager, such as the signing of new players, were the responsibility of the club's secretary, William Ironside Groombridge.[6] Most of the Gillingham players from the final season before the war did not return, and the club signed a host of new players to take their place.[7] The new signings included Arthur Wood, a forward who had last played for Fulham of the Football League Second Division; he was able to resume his career despite having suffered an injury while fighting in the war which necessitated the insertion of a metal plate into his forehead and limited his ability to head the ball.[8] Other new players to join Gillingham included Bobby Beale, a goalkeeper born in nearby Maidstone who had previously played over a hundred Football League games for Manchester United,[9] and David Chalmers, a Scottish forward who had also seen active service during the war.[10][11] The team reverted to wearing a kit of black-and-white striped shirts, white shorts, and black socks, which had been the club's colours from its formation until shortly before the war when a blue and red kit was adopted.[12][13]

Southern League Division One

August–December

Gillingham's first match of the season was at their own home ground, Priestfield Road, against Watford, the Southern League champions in the final season before the war.[14] Tom Leslie and Jack Mahon were the only players in the Gillingham team who had represented the club before the hostilities.[15] The match ended in a 0–0 draw; the correspondent for The Daily Telegraph noted that Gillingham's forwards played well and that Watford had their full-backs to thank for the fact that Gillingham could not manage to score a goal.[14] Gillingham lost two days later away to Luton Town, but then gained their first win of the season, beating Swansea Town with a goal from W. Savage; Abel Lee, another pre-war Gillingham player, made his return in the victory.[16][17] The team followed this with a home win against Luton on 10 September; Wood scored both goals.[16][18] Following this game, Gillingham failed to score in their remaining four matches in September, which resulted in one draw and three defeats.[16] The run included a 5–0 loss away to Cardiff City, in which the Cardiff-based Western Mail contended that Gillingham's defence, prior to this game one of the best in the league, had experienced a "sensational collapse" and that the home team's goalkeeper was "practically a spectator".[19]

The team's run of consecutive defeats continued in October, with a 5–2 defeat away to Swindon Town and a 2–0 loss at home to Plymouth Argyle. Full-back Bill Cartwright made his debut against Swindon.[16] Gillingham ended their losing run with a 2–0 victory at home to Millwall on 11 October; Wood again scored twice. The Daily Herald's reporter praised Millwall's goalkeeper and said that the team were fortunate to concede only two goals.[20] Beale played his last game for the club in a 3–1 defeat away to Newport County on 25 October; over the next seven games, the team used four different goalkeepers, none of whom played more than twice.[16] Changes continued to be made to the team; forward Alex Redpath made his debut against Newport and half-back A. Harris and forwards Harry Dawson and C. Denny all played for the first time against Northampton Town on 8 November. Denny never made another appearance and Dawson and Harris both played only once more.[21]

Gillingham ended November with two more defeats, losing 4–1 to Crystal Palace and 5–0 to Norwich City; the Sunday Mercury said that in the former game Crystal Palace were "easily superior" and that in the latter Norwich "toyed with their opponents".[22][23] Another new forward, H. Kelly, debuted against Norwich, as did half-backs Alex Steel and Jimmy Kennedy, signed from Southend United and Watford respectively.[16][24] The team began December with two further defeats, losing 2–0 at home to Brentford and 4–0 away to Merthyr Town; Steel's brother Bobby, a new signing from Tottenham Hotspur,[25] made his debut in the latter game as the team's latest new forward.[16][26][27] Gillingham's final three league games of 1919 took place on consecutive days beginning on Christmas Day when they lost 2–1 at home to Reading. Against the same opponents the following day, goalkeeper Jack Branfield, who had played twice for Gillingham in 1915,[4] made his return as his team lost 3–0; he would remain first-choice goalkeeper for the remainder of the season, missing only one match.[16] The team's last league game of the year took place on 27 December and resulted in a 1–1 draw away to Bristol Rovers,[28] meaning that Gillingham had gone 11 league games without a victory.[16]

January–May

Gillingham played only two league games in January and their winless run continued as they lost away to Watford and Exeter City.[16] Following a goalless draw with Queens Park Rangers, Gillingham beat Swindon Town on 14 February to end a run of 14 league games without a victory stretching back to October; Harry Lee scored twice in the victory.[16][29] The team lost their next two games, away to Millwall and at home to Brighton & Hove Albion,[30][31] and ended February bottom of the league table, five points below 21st-placed Northampton. Gillingham's total of 18 goals scored in 28 games was by far the lowest in the division; no other team had scored fewer than 30.[32]

The team began March with a third consecutive defeat, losing 4–0 away to Newport County,[16] but then achieved a goalless draw at home to Portsmouth, who were top of the table; Branfield saved a Portsmouth penalty kick.[33] The Chatham Observer praised Abel Lee and the Steel brothers for keeping the Portsmouth forwards in check, and criticised the league leaders for their aggressive style of play.[34] The Weekly Dispatch described it as a "rough game" and said that at one point players came to blows.[33] Gillingham next played another team challenging for the league championship, Cardiff City, and after taking the lead after just two minutes went on to win 3–0,[35] only the second time during the season that they had scored three goals in a league game.[16] After two more defeats, Gillingham ended March with a 2–0 win over Southampton.[16] Full-back Jock Robertson made his debut in a 1–0 victory over Southend United on 3 April. He would go on to play for the club until 1933 and make over 350 appearances in the Football League after Gillingham joined that competition in 1920, setting a club record which would stand for over 30 years.[36]

Gillingham beat Norwich City and Brentford on 10 and 17 April respectively, the first time the team had won two consecutive games since the previous September.[16][37][38] Both Steel brothers, who had been regulars in the team since joining Gillingham, were absent from the team for the next game against Swansea Town;[16] despite having to play the whole of the second half with only ten men after one of their players was injured, Swansea won 1–0.[39] There were further changes to the team for the next game at home to Merthyr Town: half-back Joseph Griffiths made his debut and Len Ramsell played for the first time since January in place of Wood. Gillingham fell behind to a goal in the first half but scored three times to record their third victory in four games; the Western Mail stated that Merthyr were "very easily beaten".[16][40][41] The team's final match of the season was a 2–2 draw at home to Bristol Rovers.[42] Gillingham finished the season bottom of the league table; although they did not have the worst defence in the division, they had scored only 34 goals during the season, more than 10 fewer than any other team.[3] Such had been the turnover of players during the season that only Leslie and Mahon were in the team for both the first and last matches of the campaign.[16]

FA Cup

Gillingham entered the 1919–20 FA Cup at the sixth and final qualifying round stage, where they were paired with fellow Southern League Division One team Swansea Town. The initial match took place at Priestfield Road and drew an attendance of 10,000, matching those recorded for league games against Brighton and Swindon for the season's largest crowd at the ground.[16] Leslie scored with a penalty kick in a game that finished in a 1–1 draw, necessitating a replay.[16] Gillingham made four team changes for the second game, including bringing in Ramsell, who scored in another 1–1 draw.[16] The second replay took place at a neutral venue, Ninian Park in Cardiff, and ended goalless.[16][43] The third replay was held at Chelsea's Stamford Bridge stadium; Gillingham took a 2–0 lead in the first half through Bobby Steel and Wood, and finally progressed to the next round, winning the game 3–1; The Daily Telegraph wrote that Gillingham were "the superior side" and that "to beat so decisively the team standing seventh in [the Southern League Division One] was a praiseworthy performance".[44]

In the first round proper, Gillingham played away to West Stanley of the North Eastern League; unlike Gillingham, West Stanley had never previously progressed beyond the qualifying rounds of the competition.[45][46] After conceding a goal early on, Gillingham drew level before half time. In the second half, however, they played poorly and West Stanley scored twice more to win the match and eliminate Gillingham from the competition. West Stanley's local newspaper called the result a "sensation" and said it would go down in the history of the mining village.[46][47]

Players

During the season, 39 players made at least one appearance for Gillingham. Leslie made the most, playing 40 times; Mahon, Wood, and Abel Lee all made more than 30 appearances. The instability of the team during the season resulted in 12 players each making fewer than five appearances.[16] Three of these, C. Denny, W. Hunter, and T. Turner, each played only once and never made another appearance for the Gillingham first team.[48]

Fifteen players scored at least one goal during the season. Wood was the team's top scorer, with 12 goals in the league and two in the FA Cup; no other player scored more than five times.[16]

Aftermath

Collins left his position as Gillingham manager at the end of the season and was replaced by Robert Brown.[49] At the annual general meeting (AGM) of the Football League on 31 May 1920, the clubs in the existing two divisions voted to admit those in the Southern League's top division en masse to form the new Third Division.[50] Initially it was unclear if Gillingham, by virtue of their last-place finish, would be relegated to the Southern League Division Two before this took effect and thus miss out on a place in the Football League; at the club's own AGM on 3 June, angry supporters demanded to know what the club's status would be for the coming season, but the board of directors was unable to give an answer. Shortly afterwards, it was confirmed that Gillingham would indeed be entering the Football League.[51] In their first season in the Third Division, the team again finished bottom of the league table.[52]

Gillingham 1919–20 football season

1920–21 [/wiki/1920%E2%80%9321_Gillingham_F.C._season] →

During the 1919–20 English football season
[/wiki/1919%E2%80%9320_in_English_football], Gillingham F.C.
[/wiki/Gillingham_F.C.] played in the Southern League
[/wiki/Southern_Football_League] Division One. It was the 22nd season in which
the club competed in the Southern League, and the 21st in Division One; prior to
the season, the club had been inactive for over four years due to the First
World War [/wiki/First_World_War]. George Collins
[/wiki/George_Collins_(footballer)] was appointed as the club's new manager
[/wiki/Manager_(association_football)], and most of the players were new; the
club struggled to find a settled team during the season, fielding nearly 40
players, including six goalkeepers [/wiki/Goalkeeper_(association_football)].
The team's results included a run of 14 league games, from October to February,
without a win. Gillingham finished bottom of the league table
[/wiki/League_table] but nonetheless gained entry to the national Football
League [/wiki/English_Football_League] when it absorbed the entirety of the
Southern League Division One.

Gillingham also competed in the FA Cup [/wiki/FA_Cup], requiring three replays
to progress from the sixth qualifying round before losing in the first round
proper. The team played 47 competitive matches, winning 11, drawing 10, and
losing 26. Arthur Wood [/wiki/Arthur_Wood_(footballer,_born_1890)] was the
team's top goalscorer, with 12 goals in the league and 14 in total. Tom Leslie
[/wiki/Tom_Leslie] made the most appearances, playing 40 times. The highest
attendance recorded at the club's home ground, Priestfield Road
[/wiki/Priestfield_Stadium], was approximately 10,000 for league games against
Swindon Town [/wiki/Swindon_Town_F.C.] and Brighton & Hove Albion
[/wiki/Brighton_%26_Hove_Albion_F.C.] and an FA Cup match against Swansea Town
[/wiki/Swansea_City_F.C.].


BACKGROUND AND PRE-SEASON

Gillingham [/wiki/Gillingham_F.C.], founded in 1893 and known as New Brompton
until 1912,[2] had played in the Southern League
[/wiki/Southern_Football_League] since the competition's formation in 1894. The
team had been promoted [/wiki/Promotion_and_relegation] from Division Two in
1895 and remained in Division One ever since but with minimal success, rarely
finishing in the top half of the league table [/wiki/League_table].[3] The
1919–20 season [/wiki/1919%E2%80%9320_Southern_Football_League] was the first
time the Southern League operated after the First World War
[/wiki/First_World_War]; Gillingham had not played a competitive match since the
1914–15 season [/wiki/1914%E2%80%9315_Southern_Football_League], when they had
finished bottom of the table.[3][4] Earlier in the year, the Southern League had
proposed an amalgamation with the national Football League
[/wiki/English_Football_League], but it was rejected.[5]

In July, George Collins [/wiki/George_Collins_(footballer)] was appointed as
Gillingham's new manager [/wiki/Manager_(association_football)] in place of Sam
Gilligan [/wiki/Sam_Gilligan], who did not return to the club after the war. As
was the norm at the time, Collins had responsibility for team tactics and
training, but other tasks associated with a modern manager, such as the signing
of new players, were the responsibility of the club's secretary, William
Ironside Groombridge [/wiki/William_Ironside_Groombridge].[6] Most of the
Gillingham players from the final season before the war did not return, and the
club signed a host of new players to take their place.[7] The new signings
included Arthur Wood [/wiki/Arthur_Wood_(footballer,_born_1890)], a forward
[/wiki/Forward_(association_football)] who had last played for Fulham
[/wiki/Fulham_F.C.] of the Football League Second Division
[/wiki/Football_League_Second_Division]; he was able to resume his career
despite having suffered an injury while fighting in the war which necessitated
the insertion of a metal plate into his forehead and limited his ability to head
the ball.[8] Other new players to join Gillingham included Bobby Beale
[/wiki/Bobby_Beale], a goalkeeper [/wiki/Goalkeeper_(association_football)] born
in nearby Maidstone [/wiki/Maidstone] who had previously played over a hundred
Football League games for Manchester United [/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C.],[9]
and David Chalmers [/wiki/David_Chalmers_(footballer,_born_1891)], a Scottish
forward who had also seen active service during the war.[10][11] The team
reverted to wearing a kit [/wiki/Kit_(association_football)] of black-and-white
striped shirts, white shorts, and black socks, which had been the club's colours
from its formation until shortly before the war when a blue and red kit was
adopted.[12][13]


SOUTHERN LEAGUE DIVISION ONE


AUGUST–DECEMBER

Portrait of a man
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/56/ArthurWoodGillingham.jpg/170px-ArthurWoodGillingham.jpg]/wiki/File:ArthurWoodGillingham.jpgArthur
Wood [/wiki/Arthur_Wood_(footballer,_born_1890)] scored both goals in
Gillingham's first home win of the season.

Gillingham's first match of the season was at their own home ground, Priestfield
Road [/wiki/Priestfield_Stadium], against Watford [/wiki/Watford_F.C.], the
Southern League champions in the final season before the war.[14] Tom Leslie
[/wiki/Tom_Leslie] and Jack Mahon [/wiki/Jack_Mahon_(footballer,_born_1886)]
were the only players in the Gillingham team who had represented the club before
the hostilities.[15] The match ended in a 0–0 draw; the correspondent for The
Daily Telegraph [/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph] noted that Gillingham's forwards
played well and that Watford had their full-backs
[/wiki/Defender_(association_football)] to thank for the fact that Gillingham
could not manage to score a goal.[14] Gillingham lost two days later away to
Luton Town [/wiki/Luton_Town_F.C.], but then gained their first win of the
season, beating Swansea Town [/wiki/Swansea_City_F.C.] with a goal from W.
Savage; Abel Lee [/wiki/Abel_Lee], another pre-war Gillingham player, made his
return in the victory.[16][17] The team followed this with a home win against
Luton on 10 September; Wood scored both goals.[16][18] Following this game,
Gillingham failed to score in their remaining four matches in September, which
resulted in one draw and three defeats.[16] The run included a 5–0 loss away to
Cardiff City [/wiki/Cardiff_City_F.C.], in which the Cardiff-based Western Mail
[/wiki/Western_Mail_(Wales)] contended that Gillingham's defence, prior to this
game one of the best in the league, had experienced a "sensational collapse" and
that the home team's goalkeeper was "practically a spectator".[19]

The team's run of consecutive defeats continued in October, with a 5–2 defeat
away to Swindon Town [/wiki/Swindon_Town_F.C.] and a 2–0 loss at home to
Plymouth Argyle [/wiki/Plymouth_Argyle_F.C.]. Full-back Bill Cartwright
[/wiki/Bill_Cartwright_(footballer,_born_1884)] made his debut against
Swindon.[16] Gillingham ended their losing run with a 2–0 victory at home to
Millwall [/wiki/Millwall_F.C.] on 11 October; Wood again scored twice. The Daily
Herald [/wiki/Daily_Herald_(United_Kingdom)]'s reporter praised Millwall's
goalkeeper and said that the team were fortunate to concede only two goals.[20]
Beale played his last game for the club in a 3–1 defeat away to Newport County
[/wiki/Newport_County_F.C.] on 25 October; over the next seven games, the team
used four different goalkeepers, none of whom played more than twice.[16]
Changes continued to be made to the team; forward Alex Redpath made his debut
against Newport and half-back [/wiki/Half-back_(association_football)] A. Harris
and forwards Harry Dawson [/wiki/Harry_Dawson_(association_footballer)] and C.
Denny all played for the first time against Northampton Town
[/wiki/Northampton_Town_F.C.] on 8 November. Denny never made another appearance
and Dawson and Harris both played only once more.[21]

Gillingham ended November with two more defeats, losing 4–1 to Crystal Palace
[/wiki/Crystal_Palace_F.C.] and 5–0 to Norwich City [/wiki/Norwich_City_F.C.];
the Sunday Mercury [/wiki/Sunday_Mercury] said that in the former game Crystal
Palace were "easily superior" and that in the latter Norwich "toyed with their
opponents".[22][23] Another new forward, H. Kelly, debuted against Norwich, as
did half-backs Alex Steel [/wiki/Alex_Steel] and Jimmy Kennedy
[/wiki/Jimmy_Kennedy_(footballer)], signed from Southend United
[/wiki/Southend_United_F.C.] and Watford respectively.[16][24] The team began
December with two further defeats, losing 2–0 at home to Brentford
[/wiki/Brentford_F.C.] and 4–0 away to Merthyr Town [/wiki/Merthyr_Town_F.C.];
Steel's brother Bobby [/wiki/Bobby_Steel], a new signing from Tottenham Hotspur
[/wiki/Tottenham_Hotspur_F.C.],[25] made his debut in the latter game as the
team's latest new forward.[16][26][27] Gillingham's final three league games of
1919 took place on consecutive days beginning on Christmas Day when they lost
2–1 at home to Reading [/wiki/Reading_F.C.]. Against the same opponents the
following day, goalkeeper Jack Branfield [/wiki/Jack_Branfield], who had played
twice for Gillingham in 1915,[4] made his return as his team lost 3–0; he would
remain first-choice goalkeeper for the remainder of the season, missing only one
match.[16] The team's last league game of the year took place on 27 December and
resulted in a 1–1 draw away to Bristol Rovers [/wiki/Bristol_Rovers_F.C.],[28]
meaning that Gillingham had gone 11 league games without a victory.[16]


JANUARY–MAY

A cartoon depicting events during the Gillingham v Portsmouth football match in
March 1920
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/57/GillinghamPortsmouthMarch1920.jpg/290px-GillinghamPortsmouthMarch1920.jpg]/wiki/File:GillinghamPortsmouthMarch1920.jpgA
cartoon printed in the Chatham Observer newspaper criticised Portsmouth
[/wiki/Portsmouth_F.C.]'s aggressive style of play in their goalless draw with
Gillingham in March.

Gillingham played only two league games in January and their winless run
continued as they lost away to Watford and Exeter City
[/wiki/Exeter_City_F.C.].[16] Following a goalless draw with Queens Park Rangers
[/wiki/Queens_Park_Rangers_F.C.], Gillingham beat Swindon Town on 14 February to
end a run of 14 league games without a victory stretching back to October; Harry
Lee [/wiki/Harry_Lee_(footballer,_born_1887)] scored twice in the
victory.[16][29] The team lost their next two games, away to Millwall and at
home to Brighton & Hove Albion [/wiki/Brighton_%26_Hove_Albion_F.C.],[30][31]
and ended February bottom of the league table, five points below 21st-placed
Northampton. Gillingham's total of 18 goals scored in 28 games was by far the
lowest in the division; no other team had scored fewer than 30.[32]

The team began March with a third consecutive defeat, losing 4–0 away to Newport
County,[16] but then achieved a goalless draw at home to Portsmouth
[/wiki/Portsmouth_F.C.], who were top of the table; Branfield saved a Portsmouth
penalty kick [/wiki/Penalty_kick_(association_football)].[33] The Chatham
Observer praised Abel Lee and the Steel brothers for keeping the Portsmouth
forwards in check, and criticised the league leaders for their aggressive style
of play.[34] The Weekly Dispatch [/wiki/Sunday_Dispatch] described it as a
"rough game" and said that at one point players came to blows.[33] Gillingham
next played another team challenging for the league championship, Cardiff City,
and after taking the lead after just two minutes went on to win 3–0,[35] only
the second time during the season that they had scored three goals in a league
game.[16] After two more defeats, Gillingham ended March with a 2–0 win over
Southampton [/wiki/Southampton_F.C.].[16] Full-back Jock Robertson
[/wiki/Jock_Robertson] made his debut in a 1–0 victory over Southend United on 3
April. He would go on to play for the club until 1933 and make over 350
appearances in the Football League after Gillingham joined that competition in
1920, setting a club record which would stand for over 30 years.[36]

Gillingham beat Norwich City and Brentford on 10 and 17 April respectively, the
first time the team had won two consecutive games since the previous
September.[16][37][38] Both Steel brothers, who had been regulars in the team
since joining Gillingham, were absent from the team for the next game against
Swansea Town;[16] despite having to play the whole of the second half with only
ten men after one of their players was injured, Swansea won 1–0.[39] There were
further changes to the team for the next game at home to Merthyr Town: half-back
Joseph Griffiths made his debut and Len Ramsell [/wiki/Len_Ramsell] played for
the first time since January in place of Wood. Gillingham fell behind to a goal
in the first half but scored three times to record their third victory in four
games; the Western Mail stated that Merthyr were "very easily
beaten".[16][40][41] The team's final match of the season was a 2–2 draw at home
to Bristol Rovers.[42] Gillingham finished the season bottom of the league
table; although they did not have the worst defence in the division, they had
scored only 34 goals during the season, more than 10 fewer than any other
team.[3] Such had been the turnover of players during the season that only
Leslie and Mahon were in the team for both the first and last matches of the
campaign.[16]

FA CUP

Gillingham entered the 1919–20 FA Cup [/wiki/1919%E2%80%9320_FA_Cup] at the
sixth and final qualifying round stage, where they were paired with fellow
Southern League Division One team Swansea Town. The initial match took place at
Priestfield Road and drew an attendance of 10,000, matching those recorded for
league games against Brighton and Swindon for the season's largest crowd at the
ground.[16] Leslie scored with a penalty kick in a game that finished in a 1–1
draw, necessitating a replay [/wiki/Replay_(sports)].[16] Gillingham made four
team changes for the second game, including bringing in Ramsell, who scored in
another 1–1 draw.[16] The second replay took place at a neutral venue, Ninian
Park [/wiki/Ninian_Park] in Cardiff, and ended goalless.[16][43] The third
replay was held at Chelsea [/wiki/Chelsea_F.C.]'s Stamford Bridge
[/wiki/Stamford_Bridge_(stadium)] stadium; Gillingham took a 2–0 lead in the
first half through Bobby Steel and Wood, and finally progressed to the next
round, winning the game 3–1; The Daily Telegraph wrote that Gillingham were "the
superior side" and that "to beat so decisively the team standing seventh in [the
Southern League Division One] was a praiseworthy performance".[44]

In the first round proper, Gillingham played away to West Stanley
[/wiki/West_Stanley_F.C.] of the North Eastern League
[/wiki/North_Eastern_League]; unlike Gillingham, West Stanley had never
previously progressed beyond the qualifying rounds of the competition.[45][46]
After conceding a goal early on, Gillingham drew level before half time. In the
second half, however, they played poorly and West Stanley scored twice more to
win the match and eliminate Gillingham from the competition. West Stanley's
local newspaper called the result a "sensation" and said it would go down in the
history of the mining village [/wiki/Pit_village].[46][47]

PLAYERS

Portrait of a man
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c6/JackBranfieldcard.jpg/170px-JackBranfieldcard.jpg]/wiki/File:JackBranfieldcard.jpgJack
Branfield [/wiki/Jack_Branfield] was one of six goalkeepers used by Gillingham
during the season. Portrait of a different man
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/1/18/JockRobertsoncard.jpg]/wiki/File:JockRobertsoncard.jpgJock
Robertson [/wiki/Jock_Robertson] began his lengthy career with Gillingham during
the season.

During the season, 39 players made at least one appearance for Gillingham.
Leslie made the most, playing 40 times; Mahon, Wood, and Abel Lee all made more
than 30 appearances. The instability of the team during the season resulted in
12 players each making fewer than five appearances.[16] Three of these, C.
Denny, W. Hunter, and T. Turner, each played only once and never made another
appearance for the Gillingham first team
[/wiki/First_team_(association_football)].[48]

Fifteen players scored at least one goal during the season. Wood was the team's
top scorer, with 12 goals in the league and two in the FA Cup; no other player
scored more than five times.[16]

AFTERMATH

Collins left his position as Gillingham manager at the end of the season and was
replaced by Robert Brown [/wiki/Robert_Brown_(football_manager)].[49] At the
annual general meeting (AGM) of the Football League on 31 May 1920, the clubs in
the existing two divisions voted to admit those in the Southern League's top
division en masse to form the new Third Division
[/wiki/Football_League_Third_Division].[50] Initially it was unclear if
Gillingham, by virtue of their last-place finish, would be relegated
[/wiki/Promotion_and_relegation] to the Southern League Division Two before this
took effect and thus miss out on a place in the Football League; at the club's
own AGM on 3 June, angry supporters demanded to know what the club's status
would be for the coming season, but the board of directors was unable to give an
answer. Shortly afterwards, it was confirmed that Gillingham would indeed be
entering the Football League.[51] In their first season in the Third Division,
the team again finished bottom of the league table.[52]
